Detailed Description

Provides custom string class for easy and optimized string manipulation.

Todo:
compute hash on insert, then use to compare instead of strcmp

an updating hash as the copy is done.

size_t  slen 
) [inline]

Create a String from a given cstring with the given strlen.

Parameters:

slen The length of the given string to use.
Precondition:
len > 0
Postcondition:

String::String ( const size_t  newSize  )  [inline, explicit]

Create an empty String container with at least the specified bytes in size.

Parameters:
newSize Reserve at least this many bytes for this String.
Postcondition:
This string's memory will also never be shrunk.

A buffer has been created.

The idea behind this is that if a specific size was asked for, the buffer is like a char buf[N];

Member Function Documentation

void String::append ( const char *  string,
int  n = -1 
) [inline]

Appends given cstring to end of buffer.

Parameters:
string The cstring to be appended.
n How many characters to copy from the string.
Postcondition:
The buffer is allocated. This is the same as inserting the string at the end of the buffer.

const char* String::c_str (  )  const [inline]

Cstring accessor.

Returns:
A null-terminated character array (cstring).
Postcondition:
The buffer size is (possibly) incremented by 1 for the '\0' character.

There is a '\0' at the end of the buffer.

The actual String size is unchanged.

int String::compare ( const String &  str,
size_t  n = 0,
size_t  start = 0 
) const

Compare our String object with another String object.

Compare our String object with another String object, but only n characters.

Parameters:
string The String object to compare to
Returns:
an integer less than, equal to, or greater than zero if our buffer is found, respectively, to be less than, to match, or be greater than str.
Parameters:
str The String object to compare to.
n The number of characters to compare.
start The index to start looking from
Returns:
an integer less than, equal to, or greater than zero if our buffer is found, respectively, to be less than, to match, or be greater than str.

Find a string in the string.

Returns:

void String::insert ( int  k,
const char *  string,
int  n = -1 
)

Insert a cstring at the given index.

Parameters:
string The cstring to be inserted.
k The index to insert at.
n Up to this many characters will be used from the string.
Postcondition:
A buffer is allocated.

If the old buffer was too small, it is enlarged.

The string is inserted at the given index.
